## Lemon Market: Continuous Quality

- Quality of car: $s\in [0,\bar{s}]$
    - pdf: $f(s) = α s^{α-1}$
    - cdf: $F(s) = s^α$
- Seller's type: $θ_1$
    - Seller's preferences: $\begin{cases}p & \text{sell} \\ θ_1s & \text{not sell} \end{cases}$
- Buyer's type: $θ_2$
    - Consumption possibilities: 1 or 0
    - Buyer's preferences: $\begin{cases}θ_2s - p & \text{buy}\\ 0 & \text{not buy}\end{cases}$
- Assume $θ_2 > θ_1$

### Perfect Information

- Trade is efficient since
$$\begin{aligned}θ_2 &> θ_1 \\
θ_2s &> θ_1s \\
p + (θ_2s - p) &> θ_1s + 0\end{aligned}$$
- Conditions for $p$: $\begin{cases}p \geq θ_1s & \text{(seller)} \\ θ_2s - p \geq 0 & \text{(buyer)}\end{cases}$ hold with $θ_2s \geq p\geq θ_1s$

### Unknown Quality

- Given price $p$
- Seller sells if 
$$\begin{aligned}θ_1s \leq p \\ s\leq \frac{p}{θ_1} \end{aligned}$$
- Buyer's expected quality  
Let $z = \frac{p}{θ_1}$, expected quality is the center of mass of $f(s)$  
$$\begin{aligned}E[s \ | \ p] &= E\Big[s \ \big| s\leq \frac{p}{θ_1}\Big] \\
&= E[s \ | \ s\leq z] \\
&= \frac{\int^z_0 s\cdot f(s)\, ds}{F(z)} \\
&= \frac{\int^z_0 s\cdot αs^{α-1}\, ds}{z^α} \\
&= α\cdot\frac{\int^z_0 s^α\, ds}{z^α} \\
&= α\cdot\frac{\frac{1}{α+1}s^{α+1}}{z^α} \bigg|_0^z \\
&= \frac{α}{α+1}\cdot z \\
&= \frac{α}{α+1}\cdot\frac{p}{θ_1}\end{aligned}$$ 
- Buyer buys if
$$\begin{aligned}θ_2\cdot E[s] - p &\geq 0 \\
θ_2\cdot\frac{α}{α+1}\cdot\frac{p}{θ_1} - p &\geq 0 \\
θ_2\cdot\frac{α}{α+1}\cdot\frac{1}{θ_1} &\geq 1 \\
θ_2 &\geq θ_1\cdot\frac{α+1}{α}\end{aligned}$$
- Since $\frac{α+1}{α}>1$, the market is smaller than efficiency

> PS1.Q1  
> There are two agents, 1 and 2.  
> Agent 1 owns a used car of quality $s$.  
> Agent 1 values his car if he keeps it with $θ_1s$.  
> Agent 2 values the car with $θ_2s$ (gross of the price to pay).  
> Assume that $θ_2 > θ_1$.
> 
> 1. If both know $s$, when is trade effcient?
> 2. Assume now that only the seller knows $s$.  
> The buyer thinks that quality $s$ is distributed in the population of cars with a uniform density on $[0, 1]$.  
> Suppose that a third person (auctioneer) announces a price $p$ at which the two persons can trade.  
> When will they trade, i.e. for which values of $s$?
> 3. Suppose now that the distribution is changed as follows, when will trade occur?
>    a. $f(s) = \frac{1}{2}s^{-\frac{1}{2}}$ on $[0, 1]$
>    b. $f(s) = 2s$ on $[0, 1]$
>    c. $f(s) = 3s^2$ on $[0, 1]$
>    d. $f(s) = 4s^3$ on $[0, 1]$
> 4. Discuss the role of taste differences and the distribution of quality for the working of the market (informally).

1. Since
$$\begin{aligned} θ_2 &> θ_1 \\
θ_2s &> θ_1s\end{aligned}$$
trade is always efficient
2. Seller accepts $p$ if 
$$\begin{aligned}p &\geq θ_1s \\
s &\leq \frac{p}{θ_1}\end{aligned}$$
Buyer accepts $p$ if
$$\begin{aligned}p &\leq θ_2\cdot E[s|p] \\
&= θ_2\cdot\frac{1}{2}\cdot\frac{p}{θ_1} \\
1 &\leq θ_2\cdot\frac{1}{2}\cdot\frac{1}{θ_1} \\
θ_2 &\geq 2θ_1\end{aligned}$$
3. Seller accepts $p$ if 
$$\begin{aligned}p\geq θ_1s \\
s &\leq \frac{p}{θ_1}\end{aligned}$$
Buyer accepts $p$ if 
$$\begin{aligned}θ_2\cdot E[s|p] &\geq p\\
θ_2 &\geq \frac{p}{E[s|p]} \end{aligned}$$
    a. For $f(s) = \frac{1}{2}s^{-\frac{1}{2}}$ 
    $$\begin{aligned}E\big[s|s\leq \frac{p}{θ_1}\big] &= \frac{\int_0^{\frac{p}{θ_1}} s\cdot f(s)\, ds}{F(\frac{p}{θ_1})} \\
    &= \frac{\int_0^{\frac{p}{θ_1}} s\cdot \frac{1}{2}s^{-\frac{1}{2}}\, ds}{\big(\frac{p}{θ_1}\big)^{\frac{1}{2}}} \\
    &= \frac{1}{\big(\frac{p}{θ_1}\big)^{\frac{1}{2}}}\cdot\int_0^{\frac{p}{θ_1}} \frac{1}{2}s^{\frac{1}{2}}\, ds \\
    &= \frac{1}{\big(\frac{p}{θ_1}\big)^{\frac{1}{2}}}\cdot\big[\frac{1}{3}s^{\frac{3}{2}}\big]_0^{\frac{p}{θ_1}} \\
    &= \frac{1}{\big(\frac{p}{θ_1}\big)^{\frac{1}{2}}}\cdot\frac{1}{3}\cdot\big(\frac{p}{θ_1}\big)^{\frac{3}{2}} \\
    &= \frac{1}{3}\cdot\frac{p}{θ_1}\end{aligned}$$
    therefore, trade occurs when $θ_2 \geq \frac{p}{E[s|p]} = 3θ_1$
    b. For $f(s) = 2s$, $E\big[s|s\leq \frac{p}{θ_1}\big] = \frac{2}{3}\cdot\frac{p}{θ_1}$  
    therefore, trade occurs when $θ_2\geq\frac{3}{2}θ_1$
    c. For $f(s) = 3s^2$, $E\big[s|s\leq \frac{p}{θ_1}\big] = \frac{3}{4}\cdot\frac{p}{θ_1}$  
    therefore, trade occurs when $θ_2\geq\frac{4}{3}θ_1$
    d. For $f(s) = 4s^3$, $E\big[s|s\leq \frac{p}{θ_1}\big] = \frac{4}{5}\cdot\frac{p}{θ_1}$  
    therefore, trade occurs when $θ_2\geq\frac{5}{4}θ_1$
4. As the distribution gets bigger on higher end, the taste difference becomes less important. 

> PS1.Q2  
> Agent 1 finds an old book in his basement and considers selling it on the flee market.  
> Agent 1's utility from keeping the book is $θ_1s$, where $s$ is the quality of the book.  
> On the flee market, agent 2 is potentially willing to buy the book.  
> Agent 2's utility from buying the book is $θ_2s - p$ if he buys at price $p$.
> 
> 1. If $s$ is publicly observed, when is trade effcient?  
> 2. Suppose now __agent 1__ does not know the value of the book.  
> Agent 2 knows $s$ but agent 1 knows only that $s\in [0, 1]$ is equally likely.  
> Suppose that an auctioneer announces a price $p$ at which trade can occur.  
> What expected value of quality can agent 1 infer from the fact that trade occurs at price $p$?
> 3. Write down the conditions that both buyer and seller are willing to trade.  
> Show that for any $θ_2 > θ_1$, it is always possible to find a price $p$ such that some trade occurs, that is, the market does not break down completely.  
> Find the smallest quality level that can be traded in the market.  
> Based on this smallest quality level that can be traded, compute the probability that $s$ exceeds the minimum level and show that this probability goes to zero as $θ_2\to θ_1$.

1. Seller sells if $p \geq θ_1 s$
Buyer buys if $θ_2s - p \geq 0$
therefore, when $θ_2 \geq θ_1$, trade is efficient. 
2. Buyer buys if 
$$\begin{aligned}θ_2s - p &\geq 0 \\
s &\geq \frac{p}{θ_2} \end{aligned}$$
Therefore, when the buyer buys, seller's expected value of $s$ is 
$$\begin{aligned}E\big[s|s\geq \frac{p}{θ_2}\big] &= \frac{\int_{\frac{p}{θ_2}}^1 s\cdot f(s)\, ds}{1 - F(\frac{p}{θ_2})} \\
&= \frac{\int_{\frac{p}{θ_2}}^1 s\, ds}{1 - \frac{p}{θ_2}} \\
&= \frac{1}{1 - \frac{p}{θ_2}}\cdot\frac{1}{2}\cdot\big[s^2\big]_{\frac{p}{θ_2}}^1 \\
&= \frac{1}{2}\cdot\frac{1}{1 - \frac{p}{θ_2}}\cdot\big(1 - \frac{p^2}{θ_2^2}\big) \\
&= \frac{1}{2}\cdot\big( 1 + \frac{p}{θ_2}\big)\end{aligned}$$
3. Seller sells if
$$\begin{aligned}p &\geq θ_1\cdot E[s] \\
&= θ_1\cdot \frac{1}{2}\cdot\big( 1 + \frac{p}{θ_2}\big) \\
p\cdot\big(\frac{2}{θ_1} - \frac{1}{θ_2}\big) &\geq 1 \\
p &\geq \frac{θ_1θ_2}{2θ_2 - θ_1}\end{aligned}$$
Buyer buys if 
$$\begin{aligned}θ_2s - p &\geq 0 \\
θ_2s &\geq p \\
&\geq\frac{θ_1θ_2}{2θ_2 - θ_1} \\
s &\geq\frac{θ_1}{2θ_2 - θ_1} \end{aligned}$$
when $θ_2 > θ_1$,
$$\begin{aligned}s^* &= \frac{θ_1}{2θ_2 - θ_1} \\
&< 1 \end{aligned}$$
therefore, exists some books better than $s^*$ that are traded  
Probability that $s>s^*$:
$$\begin{aligned}1 - F(s^*) &= 1 - \frac{θ_1}{2θ_2 - θ_1} \\
&= \frac{2(θ_2 - θ_1)}{2θ_2 - θ_1}\end{aligned}$$
as $θ_2\to θ_1$, $\frac{2(θ_2 - θ_1)}{2θ_2 - θ_1}\to 0$

### Competitive Equilibrium

- $s\in [\underline{s},\bar{s}]$
- $N$ sellers, $N$ buyers
- Sellers' type: $θ_0$ (all same)
- Buyers' type: $θ$
    - pdf: $g(θ)$
    - cdf: $G(θ)$, $G(\hat{θ}) = Pr(θ\leq \hat{θ})$
- Perfect information  
For each seller, willingness to sell: $$p(s) = θ_0\cdot s$$
For each buyer, willingness to buy: $$p(θ,s) = θ\cdot s$$
Each buyer will trade with seller with car of quality $s$ if
$$\begin{aligned} p(θ,s) &\geq p(s) \\
θ\cdot s &\geq θ_0\cdot s \\
θ &\geq θ_0\end{aligned}$$
Volume of trade: 
$$\begin{aligned} D &= N\cdot Pr(θ\geq θ_0) \\ &= N\cdot\big[ 1 - G(θ_0) \big]\end{aligned}$$
- Asymmetric information  
__Given price $p$__, sellers sell if 
$$\begin{aligned}p &\geq θ_0\cdot s \\
s &\leq \frac{p}{θ_0} \\
S(p) &= N\cdot Pr\Big(s\leq \frac{p}{θ_0}\Big) \\
&= N\cdot F\Big( \frac{p}{θ_0}\Big)\end{aligned}$$
Buyers' expected quality: $$s^e(p) := E\Big[ s \ \big| \ s\leq \frac{p}{θ_0}\Big]$$
Buyers buy if 
$$\begin{aligned} θ\cdot s^e(p) &\geq p \\
θ &\geq \frac{p}{s^e(p)} \\
D(p) &= N\cdot Pr\Big(θ \geq \frac{p}{s^e(p)}\Big) \\
&= N\Big[ 1 - G\Big(\frac{p}{s^e(p)}\Big) \Big]\end{aligned}$$
Market clears when
$$\begin{aligned}S(p) &= D(p) \\
N\cdot F\Big( \frac{p}{θ_0}\Big) &= N\Big[ 1 - G\Big(\frac{p}{s^e(p)}\Big) \Big] \\
F\Big( \frac{p}{θ_0}\Big) &= 1 - G\Big(\frac{p}{s^e(p)}\Big) \end{aligned}$$
- Locally increasing demand exists when
$$\begin{aligned}D'(p) = -N\cdot\underbrace{g\Big(\frac{p}{s^e(p)}\Big)}_{>0}\cdot\frac{\partial}{\partial p} \Big(\frac{p}{s^e(p)}\Big) & > 0 \\
-\frac{\partial}{\partial p} \Big(\frac{p}{s^e(p)}\Big) &> 0 \\
\frac{s^e(p) - \frac{\partial s^e(p)}{\partial p}\cdot p}{s^e(p)^2} &< 0 \\
s^e(p) - \frac{\partial s^e(p)}{\partial p}\cdot p &< 0 \\
\frac{\partial s^e(p)}{\partial p}\cdot\frac{p}{s^e(p)} &> 1 \\
\frac{\partial s^e(p) / s^e(p)}{\partial p / p} &> 1 \\
\text{Elasticity of expected quality} &> 1\end{aligned}$$

## Lemon Market: Binary Quality

- Quality of car: $s\in\{\underline{s},\bar{s}\}$
    - Probability that a car is $\bar{s}$: $α$
    - Probability that $\bar{s}$ does not need repair: $\bar{s} = r\cdot 1 + (1-r)\cdot 0 = r$
    - Probability that $\underline{s}$ does not need repair: $\underline{s} = q\cdot 1 + (1-q)\cdot 0 = q$
    - $r > q$
- Seller's type: $θ_1$
    - Seller's preferences: $\begin{cases}p &\text{sell} \\ θ_1\cdot 1 - (1-s)\cdot c &\text{repair} \\ s\cdot θ_1 &\text{not repair} \end{cases}$
- Buyers' type: $θ_2$, 2 buyers
    - Buyers' preferences: $\begin{cases}θ_2\cdot 1 - (1-s)\cdot c - p &\text{repair} \\ θ_2\cdot s - p &\text{not repair} \\ 0 &\text{not buy} \end{cases}$
- Assume $θ_2 > θ_1$
- Repair cost: $c$

### Cheap Repair

- $c \leq θ_1 < θ_2$
    - Seller will repair if doesn't sell:
    $$\begin{aligned}θ_1 - (1-s)\cdot c &\geq s\cdot θ_1 \\
    θ_1 - c + s\cdot c &\geq s\cdot θ_1 \\
    (s-1)\cdot c &\geq (s-1)\cdot θ_1 && (s-1<0) \\
    c &\leq θ_1\end{aligned}$$
- Seller sells if $$θ_1 - (1-s)\cdot c\leq p$$
- Buyers' expected quality: 
$$\begin{aligned} E[s] &= αr + (1-α)q \\
1 - E[s] &= 1 - \big[αr + (1-α)q\big] \\
&= 1 - αr - q + αq \\
&= 1 - αr - q + αq + α - α\\
&= α(1-r) + (1-α)(1-q)\end{aligned}$$
Buyers buy if 
$$\begin{aligned}θ_2\cdot 1 - \big(1-E[s]\big)\cdot c - p &\geq 0 \\
θ_2 - \big[α(1-r) + (1-α)(1-q)\big]\cdot c &\geq p\end{aligned}$$
- Price for $\bar{s}$ exists if 
$$\begin{aligned}θ_2 - \big[α(1-r) + (1-α)(1-q)\big]\cdot c &\geq θ_1 - (1-r)\cdot c \\
θ_2 &\geq θ_1 + \big[α(1-r) + (1-α)(1-q)\big]\cdot c - (1-r)\cdot c \\
&\geq θ_1 + (1-α)(r-q)\cdot c\end{aligned}$$
- Since $(1-α)(r-q)\cdot c > 0$, the market is smaller than efficiency

### Expensive Repair

- $c \geq θ_2 > θ_1$
    - Seller will not repair if doesn't sell: $c \geq θ_1$
    - Buyer will not repair if the car needs repair:
    $$\begin{aligned}θ_2\cdot 1 - (1-s)\cdot c - p &\leq θ_2\cdot s - p \\
    θ_2\cdot 1 - (1-s)\cdot c &\leq θ_2\cdot s \\
    (1-s)\cdot θ_2 &\leq (1-s)\cdot c \\
    θ_2 &\leq c\end{aligned}$$
- Seller sells if $$s\cdot θ_1 \leq p$$
- Buyers buy if
$$\begin{aligned}θ_2\cdot E[s] - p &\geq 0 \\
θ_2\cdot \big[αr + (1-α)q\big] &\geq p \end{aligned}$$
- Price for $\bar{s}$ exists if 
$$\begin{aligned}θ_2\cdot \big[αr + (1-α)q\big] &\geq r\cdot θ_1 \\
θ_2 &\geq \frac{r\cdot θ_1}{αr + (1-α)q} \end{aligned}$$
- Since $\frac{r}{αr + (1-α)q} > 1$, the market is smaller than efficiency

## Lemon Market: Signalling 

### Timing

1. Nature chooses quality $s$
2. Seller chooses whether to issue warranty $w$
3. Buyers propose $p$
4. Seller chooses to accept buyer 1, buyer 2 or nobody
5. (If applicable) repair

### Strategy

- Seller's strategy 
    - Warranty: $w(s): \{\underline{s},\bar{s}\} \to \{0,1\}$
    - Acceptance: $a(s,w,p_1,p_2): \{\underline{s},\bar{s}\}\times\{0,1\}\times\mathbb{R}^2 \to \{0,1,2\}$
- Buyers' strategy: $p(w): \{0,1\}\to\mathbb{R}$
- Buyers' belief: $μ(w): \{0,1\}\to [0,1]$

### Separating Equilibrium

- Assumptions
    - Expensive repair: $c \geq θ_2 > θ_1$
    - Price for $\bar{s}$ does not exist $$θ_2 < \frac{r\cdot θ_1}{αr + (1-α)q}$$
- For $\bar{s}$ seller,
$$\begin{aligned}(IC) && \underbrace{θ_2 - (1-r) \cdot c}_{\text{Sell w/ warranty}} &\geq \underbrace{q\cdot θ_2}_{\text{Sell w/o warranty}} \\
\implies && c &\leq \frac{1-q}{1-r}θ_2 \\
(PC) && \underbrace{θ_2 - (1-r) \cdot c}_{\text{Sell w/ warranty}} &\geq \underbrace{r\cdot θ_1}_{\text{Not sell}} \\
\implies && c &\leq \frac{θ_2 - r\cdot θ_1}{1-r}\end{aligned}$$
- For $\underline{s}$ seller,
$$\begin{aligned}(IC) && \underbrace{θ_2 - (1-q) \cdot c}_{\text{Sell w/ warranty}} &\leq \underbrace{q\cdot θ_2}_{\text{Sell w/o warranty}} \\
\implies && c&\geq θ_2 \\
(PC) && \underbrace{q\cdot θ_2}_{\text{Sell w/o warranty}} &\geq \underbrace{q\cdot θ_1}_{\text{Not sell}} \\
\implies && θ_2 &\geq θ_1\end{aligned}$$
- Equilibrium when $c\leq \frac{θ_2 - r\cdot θ_1}{1-r}$  
$\begin{cases} w(\bar{s}) = 1 \\ w(\underline{s}) = 0\end{cases}$, $\begin{cases}μ(1) = 1 \\ μ(0) = 0 \end{cases}$, $\begin{cases}p(1) = θ_2 \\ p(0) = q\cdot θ_2 \end{cases}$  
- When $c> \frac{θ_2 - r\cdot θ_1}{1-r}$, $\bar{s}$ seller never sells

### Pooling Equilibrium

- Pooling equilibrium with no warranty violates the assumption that market is inefficient without warranty
- Pooling equilibrium with warranty violates the assumption that repair is expensive

> Exercise  
> Solve the case of cheap (ex post effcient) repairs.

Assumptions:

1. Cheap repair: $c \leq θ_1 < θ_2$
2. Price for $\bar{s}$ does not exist $θ_2 < θ_1 + (1-α)(r-q)\cdot c$

Results:

1. Pooling equilibrium with warranty  
Buyers' belief: $\begin{cases}μ(1) = α \\ μ(0) \end{cases}$  
Buyers' willingness to buy: 
$$p = \begin{cases} θ_2 & w=1 \\
θ_2 -\big[μ(0)\cdot (1-r) + \big(1-μ(0)\big)\cdot (1-q)\big]\cdot c & w=0\end{cases}$$
For $\bar{s}$ seller,
$$\begin{aligned}(IC) && \underbrace{θ_2 - (1-r) \cdot c}_{\text{Sell w/ warranty}} &\geq \underbrace{θ_2 -\big[μ(0)\cdot (1-r) + \big(1-μ(0)\big)\cdot (1-q)\big]\cdot c}_{\text{Sell w/o warranty}} \\
\implies && \big(1-μ(0)\big)(r-q) &\geq 0 \ \text{(always holds)} \\
(PC) && \underbrace{θ_2 - (1-r) \cdot c}_{\text{Sell w/ warranty}} &\geq \underbrace{θ_1 - (1-r) \cdot c}_{\text{Not sell}} \\
\implies && θ_2&\geq θ_1\end{aligned}$$
For $\underline{s}$ seller,
$$\begin{aligned}(IC) && \underbrace{θ_2 - (1-q) \cdot c}_{\text{Sell w/ warranty}} &\geq \underbrace{θ_2 -\big[μ(0)\cdot (1-r) + \big(1-μ(0)\big)\cdot (1-q)\big]\cdot c}_{\text{Sell w/o warranty}} \\
\implies && μ(0)(q-r) &\geq 0 \\
&& μ(0) &\leq 0 \\
&& μ(0) &= 0 \\
(PC) && \underbrace{θ_2 - (1-q) \cdot c}_{\text{Sell w/o warranty}} &\geq \underbrace{θ_1 - (1-q) \cdot c}_{\text{Not sell}} \\
\implies && θ_2 &\geq θ_1\end{aligned}$$
2. Pooling equilibrium with no warranty does not exist because $\bar{s}$ seller will deviate by issuing warranty
3. Separating equilibrium  
Buyers' belief: $\begin{cases}μ(1) = r \\ μ(0) = q \end{cases}$  
Buyers' willingness to buy: $p = \begin{cases} θ_2 & w=1 \\ θ_2 - (1-q)\cdot c & w=0\end{cases}$  
For $\bar{s}$ seller,
$$\begin{aligned}(IC) && \underbrace{θ_2 - (1-r) \cdot c}_{\text{Sell w/ warranty}} &\geq \underbrace{θ_2 - (1-q)\cdot c}_{\text{Sell w/o warranty}} \\
\implies && r &\geq q \\
(PC) && \underbrace{θ_2 - (1-r) \cdot c}_{\text{Sell w/ warranty}} &\geq \underbrace{θ_1 - (1-r) \cdot c}_{\text{Not sell}} \\
\implies && θ_2&\geq θ_1\end{aligned}$$
For $\underline{s}$ seller,
$$\begin{aligned}(IC) && \underbrace{θ_2 - (1-q) \cdot c}_{\text{Sell w/ warranty}} &\leq \underbrace{θ_2 - (1-q)\cdot c}_{\text{Sell w/o warranty}} \\
\implies && q &\geq q \\
(PC) && \underbrace{θ_2 - (1-q) \cdot c}_{\text{Sell w/o warranty}} &\geq \underbrace{θ_1 - (1-q) \cdot c}_{\text{Not sell}} \\
\implies && θ_2 &\geq θ_1\end{aligned}$$
4. There is no equilibrium where a $\bar{s}$ seller does not sell

> PS2.Q1  
> Specify a pooling PBE in the following signaling game, in which both types of senders play R:  
> (Utility: Sender, Receiver)  
> ![](/post-img/notes-contract--ps2q1.png){width=500px}

1. Assume there is a pooling PBE when both types senders play R  
Therefore, receiver's on-track belief is $μ(t_1 | R) = q = 0.5$  
When sees R, receiver chooses u if 
$$\begin{aligned}1\cdot 0.5 + 0\cdot 0.5 &\geq 0\cdot 0.5 + 2\cdot 0.5 \\
0.1 &\geq 1\end{aligned}$$
therefore ,receiver alway chooses d
2. Let receiver's off-track belif be: $μ(t_1 | L) = p$,  
When sees L, receiver chooses u when
$$\begin{aligned}2\cdot p + 0\cdot (1-p)&\geq 0\cdot p + 1\cdot (1-p) \\
2p &\geq 1-p \\
p &\geq \frac{1}{3} \end{aligned}$$
however, if receiver chooses d when sees L, $t_2$ deviates by playing L since $3>2$  
therefore, receiver must choose u  
Pooling PBE: $\big\{(R,R), (u|L, d|R), p\geq \frac{1}{3}, q=0.5\big\}$

> PS2.Q2  
> The following signaling game with three types begins with a move in which the nature provides all three types with the same probability (not shown in the picture).  
> Specify a pooling PBE in which all three types of senders play L.  
> (Utility: Sender, Receiver)  
> ![](/post-img/notes-contract--ps2q2.png){width=500px}

1. Assume there is a pooling PBE when all types senders play L  
Therefore, receiver's on-track belief is $μ(t_1 | L) = μ(t_2 | L) = μ(t_3 | L)= \frac{1}{3}$  
When sees L, receiver always chooses u
2. Let receiver's off-track belief be $\begin{cases}μ(t_1 | R) = s\\μ(t_2 | R) = r \\μ(t_3 | R) = 1-s-r \end{cases}$  
When sees R, receiver chooses u when
$$\begin{aligned} 1\cdot s + 1\cdot r &\geq 1\cdot (1-s-r) \\
s + r &\geq 1-s-r \\
s+r &\geq\frac{1}{2}\end{aligned}$$
however, if receiver chooses d when sees R, $t_3$ deviates by playing R since $2>1$  
therefore, receiver must choose u  
Pooling PBE:  
$\big\{(L,L,L), (u|L, u|R), p=q=\frac{1}{3}, s\geq 0,r\geq 0,1-s-r\geq 0, s+r\geq\frac{1}{2}\big\}$

## Adverse Selection: Continuous Types

MWG Ch 13  
also see [#Lemon Market Competitive Equilibrium](#competitive-equilibrium)

- Type of workers: $θ\in [\underline{θ},\bar{θ}]$
    - pdf: $f(θ)$
    - cdf: $F(θ)$, $F(\hat{θ}) = Pr(θ\leq \hat{θ})$
- $N$ workers, many firms
- Wage: $w(θ)$
- Reservation wage: $r(θ)\geq 0$

### Benchmark

- Existence of wage  
Worker $θ$ will accept job if $w(θ) \geq r(θ)$  
Firms will employ worker $θ$ if $w(θ)\leq θ$  
Worker $θ$ will be employed if 
$$\begin{aligned}r(θ)&\leq w(θ)\leq θ \\
r(θ) &\leq θ \\
w^*(θ) &= θ\end{aligned}$$
- First best: social planner's problem  
Since firms' profit is always zero under competition, total surplus equals workers' surplus.  
Let $I(θ) =\begin{cases}0 &\text{not employed} \\ 1&\text{employed} \end{cases}$
$$\begin{aligned}\max_{I(θ)} && &\phantom{\ggg}\int_{\underline{θ}}^{\bar{θ}} N\cdot\Big[ I(θ)\cdot θ + \big(1-I(θ)\big)\cdot r(θ) \Big] \,dF(θ) \\
&& &= \int_{\underline{θ}}^{\bar{θ}} N\cdot\Big[ I(θ)\cdot θ + \big(1-I(θ)\big)\cdot r(θ) \Big]\cdot f(θ) \,dθ \\
&& &I^*(θ) = \begin{cases}0 & θ < r(θ) \\ 1 & θ \geq r(θ) \end{cases}\end{aligned}$$
- Number of employed workers: $N\cdot\big[\underbrace{1 - \underbrace{F\big(r(θ)\big)}^{Pr\big(θ\leq r(θ)\big)}}_{Pr\big(θ\geq r(θ)\big)}\big]$

### Unknown Type Competitive Equilibrium

- Assumptions $\implies E[θ]< r(\bar{θ})$ (adverse selection)
    1. $r(θ)\leq θ$ for all $θ \implies$ efficient to employ all workers
    2. $1 < r'(θ) < 0 \implies$ strictly increasing reservation wage
- Fixed wage: $w$ for all $θ$
- Set of workers accept $w$: $Θ(w) = \{θ \ | \ r(θ)\leq w\}$
- Firms' belief: $μ(w) = E[θ \ | \ r(θ)\leq w]$
    - Off-track belief: $μ = E[θ]$ when $Θ = \emptyset$
- Firms' demand for labour: $$z(w) = \begin{cases}0 & μ<w \\ [0, \infty) & μ= w \\\infty & μ>w\end{cases}$$
- Equilibrium
$$\begin{aligned}\text{Workers' BR} && Θ^* &= \{θ \ | \ r(θ)\leq w^*\} \\
\text{Firms' BR} && w^* &= E[θ \ | \ θ\in Θ^*] \\
&& &= E[θ \ | \ r(θ)\leq w^*]\end{aligned}$$
- Adverse selection arises in step 4 & 5
    1. When $w<r(θ)$, no worker accept
    2. When $w=r(\underline{θ})$, only worker $\underline{θ}$ accepts
    3. In equilibrium, $E[θ \ | \ r(θ)\leq w^*] = w^*$
    4. When $w=r(\bar{θ})$, all workers accept, $E[θ \ | \ r(θ)\leq w] = E[θ]$
    5. When $w>r(\bar{θ})$, since $E[θ] = \text{sup} \ E[θ \ | \ r(θ)\leq w]$, the function stays constant

![MWG Figure 13.B.1](/post-img/notes-institution--adverse-selection-eq.png){width=493px}

### SPNE

- Common knowledge: $F(\cdot)$, $r(\cdot)$ (strictly increasing)
- Timing
    1. 2 firms announce fixed wages separately
    2. Workers decide which firm to work for, randomize if indifferent
- Proposition 13.B.1
    - $w^*>r(\underline{θ})$ and exists $ε>0$ s.t. $E\big[ θ|r(θ)\leq w']$ for all $w'\in( w^*-ε,w^*)$  
    $\implies$ unique pure strategy SPNE: $w=w^*$, $Θ(w^*) = \big\{θ: r(θ)\leq w^*\big\}$
    - $w^*=r(\underline{θ})$  
    $\implies$ multiple pure strategy SPNE, workers enjoy utility par to highest competitive outcome
    - Firms have zero profit under any SPNE

### Constrained (Second-Best) Pareto Optimum

- First best $\subset$ second best
- Government (social planner) intervention
    - Wage: $w_e$
    - Unemployment benefit: $w_u$ 
    - Set of workers accept $w_e$: $Θ = \{θ \ | \ w_u+r(θ)\leq w_e\}$
- Assume social planner wants to let $θ\leq\hat{θ}$ accept the job  
$$\begin{aligned}\text{Marginal type} && &w_u + r(\hat{θ}) = w_e \\
\text{Budget balance} && &\underbrace{w_e\cdot F(\hat{θ})}_{\text{Total wage}} + \underbrace{w_u\cdot\big(1 - F(\hat{θ})\big)}_{\text{Total unemployment benefit}} = \underbrace{\int_θ^{\hat{θ}} θ\cdot f(θ)\, dθ}_{\text{Total productivity}}\end{aligned}$$
solving the system gives  
$$\begin{aligned}\big(w_u + r(\hat{θ})\big)&\cdot F(\hat{θ}) + w_u\cdot\big(1 - F(\hat{θ})\big) = \int_{\underline{θ}}^{\hat{θ}} θ\cdot f(θ)\, dθ \\
w_u(\hat{θ}) &= - r(\hat{θ})\cdot F(\hat{θ}) + \int_{\underline{θ}}^{\hat{θ}} θ\cdot f(θ)\, dθ \\
&= - r(\hat{θ})\cdot F(\hat{θ}) + F(\hat{θ})\cdot E[θ \ | \ θ\leq\hat{θ}]\\
&= F(\hat{θ})\cdot \big(E[θ \ | \ θ\leq\hat{θ}] - r(\hat{θ})\big) \\
w_e(\hat{θ}) &= r(\hat{θ})\cdot\big(1- F(\hat{θ})\big) + \int_{\underline{θ}}^{\hat{θ}} θ\cdot f(θ)\, dθ \\
&= F(\hat{θ})\cdot \big(E[θ \ | \ θ\leq\hat{θ}] - r(\hat{θ})\big) + r(\hat{θ})\end{aligned}$$
- When $\hat{θ} = θ^*$ in [#Unknown Type Competitive Equilibrium](#unknown-type-competitive-equilibrium)  
$$\begin{aligned}w_u(θ^*) &= F(θ^*)\cdot \big(E[θ \ | \ θ\leq θ^*] - r(θ^*)\big) \\
&= F(θ^*)\cdot 0 = 0 \\
w_e(θ^*) &= w_u(θ^*) + r(θ^*) \\
&= r(θ^*) = w^*\end{aligned}$$
- When $\hat{θ} < θ^*$
$$\begin{aligned}r(\hat{θ}) &< r(θ^*) \\
w_e(\hat{θ}) &= r(\hat{θ})\cdot\big(\overbrace{1- F(\hat{θ})}^{>0}\big) + \int_{\underline{θ}}^{\hat{θ}} θ\cdot f(θ)\, dθ \\
&< r(θ^*)\cdot\big(1- F(\hat{θ})\big) + \int_{\underline{θ}}^{\hat{θ}} θ\cdot f(θ)\, dθ \\
w_e(\hat{θ}) - r(θ^*) &< -r(θ^*)\cdot F(\hat{θ}) + \int_{\underline{θ}}^{\hat{θ}} θ\cdot f(θ)\, dθ \\
&= - r(θ^*)\cdot F(\hat{θ}) + F(\hat{θ})\cdot E[θ \ | \ θ\leq\hat{θ}]\\
&= F(\hat{θ})\cdot \big(E[θ \ | \ θ\leq\hat{θ}] - r(θ^*)\big) \\
&= F(\hat{θ})\cdot \big(E[θ \ | \ θ\leq\hat{θ}] - E[θ \ | \ θ\leq θ^*]\big) \\
&< 0 \\
w_e(\hat{θ}) &< r(θ^*) \\
&= w_e(θ^*)\end{aligned}$$
Therefore, workers who work both before and after government intervention are strictly worse-off
- When $\hat{θ} > θ^*$  
$$\begin{aligned}r(\hat{θ}) &> r(θ^*) \\
w_u(\hat{θ}) &= -r(\hat{θ})\cdot F(\hat{θ}) + \int_{\underline{θ}}^{\hat{θ}} θ\cdot f(θ)\, dθ \\
&< -r(θ^*)\cdot \cdot F(\hat{θ}) + \int_{\underline{θ}}^{\hat{θ}} θ\cdot f(θ)\, dθ \\
&= -r(θ^*)\cdot F(\hat{θ}) + F(\hat{θ})\cdot E[θ \ | \ θ\leq\hat{θ}]\\
&= F(\hat{θ})\cdot \big(E[θ \ | \ θ\leq\hat{θ}] - r(θ^*)\big) \\
&= F(\hat{θ})\cdot \big(E[θ \ | \ θ\leq\hat{θ}] - E[θ \ | \ θ\leq θ^*]\big) \\
&< 0 = w_u(θ^*)\\
w_u(\hat{θ}) &< w_u(θ^*)\end{aligned}$$
Therefore, workers who don't work both before and after government intervention are strictly worse-off

## Job Market Signalling

- Type of workers: $η\in\{H, L\}$
    - Utility function: $u(w,e\ |\ θ) = w - c(η,e)$
    - Reservation wage: $r(θ)\geq 0$
    - $Pr(η = H) = q$
- Education (signal): $e\geq 0$
    - Cost of education: $c(η,e)$
    - $c(η,0)=0$ for all η
    - $c_e>0$, $c_{ee}>0$
    - $c_η<0 \implies c(L,e)>c(H,e)$  
    $c_{ηe}<0 \implies c_e(L,e)>c_e(H,e)$  
    $\implies$ cost & marginal cost are lower for high type
- Firms' productivity: $y(η, e)$
    - Belief: $μ(e)=Pr(η = H \ | \ e)$  
    - Optimal wage:
    $$w(e) = μ(e)\cdot y(H,e) + \big( 1-μ(e)\big)\cdot y(L,e)$$

![PGT Figure 4.2.3 Workers' indifference curves: __single-crossing__](/post-img/notes-contract--job-signal-indiff-curves.png){width=335px}

![PGT Figure 4.2.4 Firms' isoprofit lines](/post-img/notes-contract--job-signal-isoprofit.png){width=440px}

- First best (types are observable)  
Social planner's problem:
$$\begin{aligned}\max_e && &\phantom{\ggg}\big(y(η, e) - w\big) + \big( w - c(η,e)\big) \\
&& &= y(η, e) - c(η,e) \\
FOC && \frac{\partial}{\partial e} &= \frac{\partial y(η, e)}{\partial e} - \frac{\partial c(η,e)}{\partial e}\overset{!}{=} 0 \\
&& e^* &= e^*(η)\end{aligned}$$
    - No envy case
    $$\begin{aligned}\text{Type L} && e^*(L) \succsim_L e^*(H) \\
    \text{Type H} && e^*(H) \succsim_H e^*(L)\end{aligned}$$ 
    ![PGT Figure 4.2.5](/post-img/notes-contract--job-signal-no-envy.png){width=469px}
    - Envy case
    $$\begin{aligned}\text{Type L} && e^*(H) \succsim_L e^*(L) \\
    \text{Type H} && e^*(H) \succsim_H e^*(L)\end{aligned}$$ 
    ![PGT Figure 4.2.6](/post-img/notes-contract--job-signal-envy.png){width=439px}

### Pooling Equilibria

- Strategy profile: $\{e_p, w(e), μ(e)\}$
1. One possibility
- Firms' belief: $μ(e)= \begin{cases}0 & e<e_p \\ q & e=e_p \\ 0 & e> e_p \end{cases}$
- Optimal wage:
$$\begin{aligned}w(e) &= μ(e)\cdot y(H,e) + \big( 1-μ(e)\big)\cdot y(L,e)\\
&= \begin{cases}w_p & e=e_p \\ y(L,e) & e\neq e_p \end{cases}\end{aligned}$$
- Workers' problem:
$$\begin{aligned}\max_e && w(e) - c(η,e) \end{aligned}$$
    - Let $(w',e')\sim_L \big(w^*(L),e^*(L)\big)$
    - Low type chooses $e = e_p$ when $e_p < e'$
    - High type chooses $e = e_p$ since $μ(e> e_p)=0$

![PGT Figure 4.2.7](/post-img/notes-contract--job-signal-pooling-1.png){width=521px}

2. Another possibility
- Firms' belief: $μ(e)= \begin{cases}0 & e<e_p \\ q & e=e_p \\ 0 & e\in(e_p,e''] \\q & e>e''\end{cases}$
- Optimal wage:
$$w(e) = \begin{cases}y(L,e) & e<e_p \\ w_p & e=e_p \\ y(L,e) & e\in(e_p,e''] \\ w_p & e>e''\end{cases}$$
- Workers
    - Let $(w',e')\sim_L \big(w^*(L),e^*(L)\big)$  
    $(w'',e'')\sim_H (w_p,e_p)$  
    - Low type chooses $e = e_p$ when $e^*(L)\leq e_p \leq e'$
    - High type chooses $e = e_p$ since $μ(e> e'')=q$

![PGT Figure 4.2.8](/post-img/notes-contract--job-signal-pooling-2.png){width=516px}

### Separating Equilibria: Non-Envy Case

- Strategy profile: $\{L:e^*(L), H:e^*(H), w(e), μ(e)\}$

### Separating Equilibria: Envy Case

- Strategy profile: $\{L:e^*(L), H:e_s, w(e), μ(e)\}$
1. One possibility
- Firms' belief: $μ(e) = \begin{cases}0 & e<e_s \\ 1 & e\geq e_s \end{cases}$
- Contraints
$$\begin{aligned}(IC)_L && w^*(L) - c\big(L, e^*(L)\big) &\geq w(e_s) - c(L, e_s) \\
(PC)_H && w(e_s) - c(H, e_s) &\geq 0 \\
\text{Firm} && w(e_s) &= y(H, e_s)\end{aligned}$$
- Optimal wage: 
$$w(e) = \begin{cases}y(L,e) & e<e_s \\ y(H,e) & e\geq e_s \end{cases}$$
- Workers
    - Let $\big(w(e_s), e_s\big)\sim_L \big(w^*(L),e^*(L)\big)$
    - Low type chooses $e = e^*(L)$ when $(IC)_L$ holds
    - High type chooses $e = e_s$ since $μ(e<e_s) = 0$

![PGT Figure 4.2.8](/post-img/notes-contract--job-signal-separate-1.png){width=433px}

2. Another possibility
- Firms' belief: $μ(e) = \begin{cases}0 & e\leq e^*(H) \\ ε & e\in\big(e^*(H), e_s\big) \\ 1 & e\geq e_s \end{cases}$

> PS3.Q1  
> Consider the following the signalling model where workers choose education levels to signal their productivity.  
> Suppose workers have a type $θ\in [0,1]$.  
> A worker's type determines his cost of acquiring education, e.  
> For a worker of type $θ > 0$, the cost of education is given by $c(θ,e) = \frac{e^2}{θ}$.  
> For a worker of type $θ = 0$; the cost of any positive level of education is equal to some (extremely) high level $K$, and the cost of zero education to that worker is zero.  
> If a worker (with a positive $θ$) gets hired at wage $w$ and chooses education level $e$, then his utility is $u=w-\frac{e^2}{θ}$.  
> Likewise, the utility of type zero is either $w -K$ or just $w$, depending on whether $e = 0$ or $e > 0$.  
> Assume that $θ$ is drawn from the unit interval $[0, 1]$, moreover, $θ$ is distributed uniformly over the interval.  
> If a firm hires a worker of productivity $θ$; the the firm's profit is $π = θ-w$.  
> Derive a perfect Bayesian equilibrium, where workers below some critical type $θ'$ pool and workers in $θ\in[θ',1]$ separate.  
> Hints: 
>
> 1. Construct an equilibrium where the low types pool on $e = 0$;
> 2. For the high types ($θ\in[θ',1]$), more precisely, for the education levels that these types choose), assume that there is a differentiable and concave wage function  
> and then find this wage function assuming that workers optimize and firms compete,  
> so their profits must be zero type by type over a range where workers separate. 
> 3. Compute the equilibrium wage for types below $θ'$, that is, the value for the wage function at $e = 0$
> 4. Verify that type $θ'$ is indifferent between separating and pooling with the low types.

From hint 1:  
Let all workers with $θ\in [0, θ')$ choose $e=0$  
therefore, the expected productivity is
$$\begin{aligned}E[ θ\ |\ θ<θ'] &= \frac{θ'}{2} \\
w_L &= E[ θ\ |\ θ<θ'] \\
&= \frac{θ'}{2} \end{aligned}$$
For $θ\in [θ',1]$, workers' problem:
$$\begin{aligned}\max_e && w_H - \frac{e^2}{θ}& \\
FOC && w_H' - 2\cdot\frac{e}{θ} &\overset{!}{=} 0 \end{aligned}$$
Since firms make zero profit,
$$\begin{aligned}π &= θ-w = 0 \\
w_H &= w\big( e(θ)\big) \\
&= θ\end{aligned}$$
plug in FOC
$$\begin{aligned}w_H' - 2\cdot\frac{e}{w_H} &= 0 \\
w_H'\cdot w_H &= 2e \\
w_H &= \sqrt{2} e\end{aligned}$$
plug in
$$\begin{aligned}\max_e && \sqrt{2} e - \frac{e^2}{θ}& \\
FOC && \sqrt{2} - 2\cdot\frac{e}{θ} &\overset{!}{=} 0 \\
&& e^*(θ) &= \frac{θ}{\sqrt{2}} \\
&& w_H &= θ \\
&& u &= w - \frac{e^2}{θ} \\
&& &= \frac{θ}{2}\end{aligned}$$
(IC) for low type:
$$\begin{aligned}w_L - 0 &\overset{!}{\geq} w_H - \frac{e^2}{θ} \\
\frac{θ'}{2} &\overset{!}{\geq} θ - \frac{(θ/\sqrt{2})^2}{θ} \\
\frac{θ'}{2} &\overset{!}{\geq} \frac{θ}{2}\end{aligned}$$
this holds for workers with $θ\in [0, θ')$,  
and holds equal (indifference) for workers with $θ = θ'$.

> Mock.Q3  
> A worker knows her talent $θ$, but the employer does not.  
> The value of the worker to the employer is $Ε[θ]$ (given the employers information, including what he learns through the game).  
> The employer pays the worker a wage equal to this expectation over talent, $w = Ε[θ]$, where the expectation operator is understood as conditional on all information available.  
> This is a shortcut to model competition between employers.  
> Prior to meeting the employer, the worker can choose a level of eduction $e$.  
> The worker's payoff function is $w - \frac{e}{θ}$.  
> The worker can be of either of two types, $θ\in\{ θ_l, θ_h\}$ with probability $Pr(θ_h) = p$.  
> $e$ is a continuous variable.  
> Timing: First, Nature determines the worker's type.  
> Then the worker observes Nature's move and chooses a level of education.  
> The employer does not observe Nature's move, but he does observe the worker's education choice and makes wage offers contingent on the education choice.  
> The equilibrium concept is Perfect Bayesian Equilibrium.
> 
> 1. Characterize pooling equilibria where both worker types choose the same level of education.  
> Be careful to discuss the employer's off equilibrium path beliefs and the resulting wage schedule.
> 2. Suppose $e^*$ is a pooling level of education.  
> Assuming that the employer believes that $θ = θ_l$ if $e\neq e^*$, characterize all possible levels of $e^*$.
> 3. Characterize separating equilibria where the high type chooses a different level of education than the low type.
> 4. Discuss the worker's (type by type) and the employer's preferences over the different separating equilibria.
> 5. Is it possible that both worker types are better-off in a pooling equilibrium relative to a separating equilibrium? Discuss.

1. Pooling equilibrium  
Assume that both types pool on $e = e_p$  
Employer's belief: $μ(e) = \begin{cases}p & e = e_p \\ 0 & e\neq e_p \end{cases}$  
When sees $e=e_p$, employer offers
$$\begin{aligned}w_p &= E[θ] \\ &= pθ_h + (1-p)θ_l\end{aligned}$$
When sees $e\neq e_p$, employer offers
$$w = θ_l$$
High type does not deviate if
$$\begin{aligned}w_p - \frac{e_p}{θ_h} &\geq \max_{e\neq e_p} \ θ_l - \frac{e}{θ_h} \\
pθ_h + (1-p)θ_l - \frac{e_p}{θ_h} &\geq θ_l \\
p(θ_h - θ_l) - \frac{e_p}{θ_h} &\geq 0\end{aligned}$$
Low type does not deviate if
$$\begin{aligned}w_p - \frac{e_p}{θ_l} &\geq \max_{e\neq e_p} \ θ_l - \frac{e}{θ_l} \\
pθ_h + (1-p)θ_l - \frac{e_p}{θ_l} &\geq θ_l \\
p(θ_h - θ_l) - \frac{e_p}{θ_l} &\geq 0\end{aligned}$$
2. Since $θ_l< θ_h$,
$$\begin{aligned}\frac{1}{θ_l} &> \frac{1}{θ_h} \\
\frac{e_p}{θ_l} &> \frac{e_p}{θ_h} \\
-\frac{e_p}{θ_l} &< - \frac{e_p}{θ_h} \\
p(θ_h - θ_l) - \frac{e_p}{θ_l} &< p(θ_h - θ_l) - \frac{e_p}{θ_h}\end{aligned}$$
therefore, $e_p$ must be s.t. $e_p\leq p(θ_h - θ_l)θ_l$
3. Seperating equilibrium  
Assume that high type chooses $e_h$, low type chooses $e_l$  
Employer's belief: $μ(e) = \begin{cases}1 & e = e_h \\ 0 & e\neq e_l \end{cases}$
Low type maximize 
$$\begin{aligned}\max_{e} && θ_l &- \frac{e}{θ_l} \\
FOC && e_l &= 0 \end{aligned}$$
High type does not deviate if
$$\begin{aligned}θ_h - \frac{e_h}{θ_h} &\geq θ_l - \frac{e_l}{θ_h} \\
θ_h^2 - e_h &\geq θ_hθ_l \\
e_h &\leq θ_h(θ_h - θ_l)\end{aligned}$$
Low type does not deviate if
$$\begin{aligned}θ_l - \frac{e_l}{θ_l} &\geq θ_h - \frac{e_h}{θ_l} \\
θ_l^2 &\geq θ_hθ_l - e_h \\
e_h &\geq θ_l(θ_h - θ_l)\end{aligned}$$
4. In seperating equilibrium, low type's payoff: $θ_l$  
We know
$$\begin{aligned}e_h &\in \big[θ_l(θ_h - θ_l), θ_h(θ_h - θ_l)\big] \\
\frac{e_h}{θ_h} &\in \big[\frac{θ_l}{θ_h}(θ_h - θ_l), (θ_h - θ_l)\big] \end{aligned}$$
therefore, high type's payoff:
$$θ_h - \frac{e_h}{θ_h}\in\big[θ_l, θ_h - \frac{θ_l(θ_h - θ_l)}{θ_h}\big]$$
So the higher $e_h$ is, the worse-off high type is.
5. In pooling equilibrium, low type's payoff: $pθ_h + (1-p)θ_l - \frac{e_p}{θ_l}$  
they are better off than in seperating equilibrium when
$$\begin{aligned}pθ_h + (1-p)θ_l - \frac{e_p}{θ_l} &\geq θ_l \\
p(θ_h - θ_l) - \frac{e_p}{θ_l} &\geq 0 \\
p &\geq \frac{e_p}{θ_l(θ_h - θ_l)}\end{aligned}$$
High type's payoff: $pθ_h + (1-p)θ_l - \frac{e_p}{θ_h}$  
they are better off than in seperating equilibrium when
$$\begin{aligned}pθ_h + (1-p)θ_l - \frac{e_p}{θ_h} &\geq θ_h - \frac{e_h}{θ_h} \\
&\geq θ_h - \frac{θ_l(θ_h - θ_l)}{θ_h} \\
pθ_h(θ_h - θ_l) &\geq (θ_h - θ_l)^2 \\
p &\geq \frac{θ_h - θ_l}{θ_h} \\
&= 1 - \frac{θ_l}{θ_h}\end{aligned}$$
Therefore, when $p$ is large enough, both types are better-off in pooling equilibrium

### Hybrid (Mixed) Equilibrium

- Strategy profile: $\{L: π\cdot e_h+(1-π)\cdot e^*(L), H: e_h, w(e), μ(e)\}$
- Firms' belief: $μ(e) = \begin{cases}0 & e<e_h \\ r & e\geq e_h\end{cases}$
$$\begin{aligned}r &= \frac{q}{q+(1-q)π} \\
r-q &= \frac{q - q^2 - (1-q)qπ}{q + (1-q) π} \\
&= \frac{q(1-π) - q^2( 1-π)}{q + (1-q) π} \\
&= \frac{q(1-q)(1-π)}{q + (1-q) π} > 0 \\
\implies r> q &\end{aligned}$$
- Optimal wage: 
$$w(e) = \begin{cases}y(L,e) & e<e_h \\ r\cdot y(H,e_h) + (1-r)y(L,e_h) & e\geq e_h \end{cases}$$

> $$μ(H|e) = \begin{cases}0 & e<e_p \\ 0.5 & e\geq e_p\end{cases}$$
> 2. Suppose firms have beliefs 
> $$μ(H|e) = \begin{cases}0 & e<e_h \\ y & e= e_h \\ 0 & e>e_h\end{cases}$$
> Compute the education levels in hybrid equilibria where the low type mixes between $e = 0.5$ and $e = e_h$ as a function of $π$, the probability that the low type chooses $e_h$.

0. Separating equilibrium
Low type's problem:
$$\begin{aligned}\max_{e} && 1&+e - e^2 \\
FOC && e^*(L) &= 0.5 \\
&& 1&+e^*(L) - \big(e^*(L)\big)^2 = 1.25\end{aligned}$$
plug in high type wage scheme
$$\begin{aligned}2+e_s - e_s^2 &= 1.25 \\
e_s &= 1.5 \end{aligned}$$
High type's problem:
$$\begin{aligned}\max_{e} && 2&+e - \frac{e^2}{2} \\
FOC && e^*(H) &= 1 \end{aligned}$$
therefore, this is an envy case.  
Low type choose $e = e^*(L) = 0.5$  
High type choose $e = e_s = 1.5$  
Firm's rational belief: $μ(H|e) = \begin{cases}0 & e<e_s \\ 1 & e\geq e_s\end{cases}$
1. Pooling equilibrium  
With beliefs $μ(H|e) = \begin{cases}0 & e<e_p \\ 0.5 & e\geq e_p\end{cases}$,  
when facing $e<e_p$, firm gives $w(e) = 1+e$  
when facing $e\geq e_p$, 
$$\begin{aligned}w(e) &= E[θ] \\
&= λ(1+e) + (1-λ)(2+e) \\
&= 1.5 + e \end{aligned}$$
therefore, firm offers wage $w(e) = \begin{cases}1 + e & e<e_p \\ 1.5 + e & e\geq e_p\end{cases}$  
Low type's problem:
$$\begin{aligned}\max_{e\geq e_p} && 1.5 &+ e - e^2 \\
FOC && e^* &= 0.5 \end{aligned}$$
therefore, $e_p\geq\frac{1}{2}$ (not willing to give lower level)  
(IC)L:
$$\begin{aligned}1.5 + e_p - e_p^2 &\geq\max_{e< e_p} \ 1+e - e^2 \\
&\geq 1 + \frac{1}{2} - \big(\frac{1}{2}\big)^2 \\
&= 1.25 \\
e_p - e_p^2 &\geq -0.25 \\
e_p &\in \big[0, \frac{1}{2}(1+\sqrt{2})\big] \end{aligned}$$
High type's problem:
$$\begin{aligned}\max_{e\geq e_p} && 1.5 &+ e - \frac{e^2}{2} \\
FOC && e^* &= 1 \end{aligned}$$
therefore, $e_p\geq 1$ (not willing to give lower level)  
(IC)H: (slack) 
$$\begin{aligned}1.5 + e_p - \frac{e_p^2}{2} &\geq \max_{e< e_p} \ 1+e - \frac{e^2}{2} \\
&\geq 1 + 1 - \frac{1^2}{2} \\
&= 1.5 \\
e_p - \frac{e_p^2}{2} &\geq 0 \\
e_p &\in [0,2] \end{aligned}$$
Therefore, $e_p\in\big[1, \frac{1}{2}(1+\sqrt{2})\big]$
2. Hybrid equilibrium  
Since type L mixes between $e=0.5$ and $e=e_h$, $π\in[0,1]$,   
firm's belief according to Bayes' rule is 
$$\begin{aligned}y &= \frac{0.5}{0.5 + 0.5\cdot π} \\
&= \frac{1}{1+π} \\
&\in \big[ \frac{1}{2},1\big] \end{aligned}$$
With beliefs $μ(H|e) = \begin{cases}0 & e\neq e_h \\ y & e= e_h\end{cases}$  
When facing $e\neq e_h$, firm gives $w(e) = 1+e$  
When facing $e= e_h$, 
$$\begin{aligned}w(e) &= E[θ] \\
&= (1-y)(1+e) + y(2+e) \\
&= (1+y) + e \end{aligned}$$
therefore, firm gives wage $w(e) = \begin{cases}1 + e & e\neq e_h \\ (1+y) + e & e= e_h\end{cases}$  
(IC)L:
$$\begin{aligned}(1+y) + e_h - e_h^2 &= \max_{e\neq e_h} \ 1+e - e^2 \\
(1+y) + e_h - e_h^2 &= 1.25 \\
e_h - e_h^2 &= 0.25 - y \\
y &= 0.25 - e_h + e_h^2 \\
0.25 - e_h + e_h^2 &\in \big[ \frac{1}{2},1\big] \\
e_h &\in \big[\frac{1}{2}(1+\sqrt{2}),\frac{3}{2}\big]\end{aligned}$$
(IC)H: (slack) 
$$\begin{aligned}(1+y) + e_h - \frac{e_h^2}{2}&\geq \max_{e\neq e_h} \ 1+e - \frac{e^2}{2} \\
(1+y) + e_h - \frac{e_h^2}{2}&\geq 1.5 \\
e_h - \frac{e_h^2}{2}&\geq 0.5-y \\
y &\geq 0.5 - e_h +\frac{e_h^2}{2} \\
e_h &\in [0,2] \end{aligned}$$
therefore, $e_h\in \big[\frac{1}{2}(1+\sqrt{2}),\frac{3}{2}\big]$

> PS2.Q4  
> In PS2.Q3, let the cost of the low type be $c_L(e)=e^2$ and let the cost of the high type be $c_H(e)= \frac{e^2}{τ}$ with $τ\geq 1$.  
> For what levels of $τ$ can you construct a separating equilibrium with __monotonic beliefs__ such that the first-best education choices are chosen in equilibrium.  
> (i.e. when do you get the envy, when the no-envy case?)  

Assume that exists some $e_s$ s.t.  
Firm's belief: $μ(H|e) = \begin{cases}0 & e<e_s \\ 1 & e\geq e_s\end{cases}$  
therefore, firm offers wage $w(e) = \begin{cases}1 + e & e<e_s \\ 2 + e & e\geq e_s\end{cases}$  
Low type's problem:
$$\begin{aligned}\max_{e} && 1&+e - e^2 \\
FOC && e^*(L) &= 0.5 \\
&& 1&+e^*(L) - \big(e^*(L)\big)^2 = 1.25\end{aligned}$$
(IC)L:
$$\begin{aligned}1.25 &\geq 2 + e_s - e_s^2 \\
e_s &\geq 1.5\end{aligned}$$
High type's problem:
$$\begin{aligned}\max_{e} && 2+e &- \frac{e^2}{τ} \\
FOC && 1 - \frac{2}{τ}e &\overset{!}{=} 0 \\
&& e^*(H) &= \frac{τ}{2} \geq 1.5 \\
&& τ&\geq 3 \end{aligned}$$
therefore, when $τ\geq 3$, there exists a separating equilibrium (non-envy case)

> PS2.Q5  
> In PS2.Q3, is it possible that a pooling equilibrium is Pareto better than any separating equilibrium?  
> In particular, vary the parameter $λ$.

<!-- See Mock.Q3.5  
Compare low type's payoff in SE and PE  
Compare high type's payoff in SE and PE  
Conclude the results -->

When varying $λ$, the expected productivity in pooling equilibrium is
$$\begin{aligned}λ\cdot 1 + (1-λ)\cdot 2 + e &= λ + 2 - 2λ + e \\
&= 2-λ + e \end{aligned}$$
In pooling equilibrium, low type gets
$$\begin{aligned}(2-λ) + e_p - e_p^2 &\geq 1 + 0.5 - 0.5^2 \\
&= 1.25\end{aligned}$$
high type gets
$$\begin{aligned}(2-λ) + e_p - \frac{e_p^2}{2} &\geq 2 + 1.5 - \frac{1.5^2}{2} \\
&= 2.375\end{aligned}$$
therefore, pooling equilibrium is Pareto better if
$$λ \leq\begin{cases}0.75 + e_p - e_p^2 \\ -0.375 + e_p - \frac{e_p^2}{2} \end{cases}$$
Specially, when $e_p\in [1,1.5]$, $0.75 + e_p - e_p^2\geq -0.375 + e_p - \frac{e_p^2}{2}$, 
$$λ \leq -0.375 + e_p - \frac{e_p^2}{2}$$
when $e_p\in\big( 1.5, \frac{1}{2}(1+\sqrt{2})\big]$, $0.75 + e_p - e_p^2 < -0.375 + e_p - \frac{e_p^2}{2}$, 
$$λ \leq 0.75 + e_p - e_p^2$$

### Perfect Bayesian Equilibrium (PBE)

MWG 9, 13.C, PGT 4.1

- On the equilibrium path  
An information set that will be readied with $Pr>0$ if the game is played according to the equilibrium strategies
- Off the equilibrium path  
An information set that is not to be reached
- PBE: strategies and beliefs satisfying Requirements 1 ~ 4
- Requirement 1  
Player at each information set must have a __belief__, aka a probability distribution over the following nodes
<!-- At each information set, the player with the move must have a __belief__ about which node in the information set has been reached by the play of the game.  
For a nonsingleton information set, a belief is a probability distribution over the nodes in the information set;  
for a singleton information set, the player's belief puts probability one on the single decision node. -->
- Requirement 2  
Players' strategies must be __sequentially rational__, aka optimal, given their beliefs and other player's strategies at each information set
<!-- Given their beliefs, the players' strategies must be __sequentially rational__,  
At each information set the action taken by the player with the move (and the player's subsequent strategy) must be optimal given the player's belief at that information set and the other players' subsequent strategies.  
A subsequent strategy is a complete plan of action covering every contingency that might arise after the given information set has been reached). -->
- Requirement 3 & 4  
Beliefs are determined by __Bayesian rule__ and the players' equilibrium strategies at information sets
<!-- At information sets on the equilibrium path, beliefs are determined by Bayesian rule and the players' equilibrium strategies.
- Requirement 4  
At information sets off the equilibrium path, beliefs are determined by Bayesian rule and the players' equilibrium strategies when possible. -->
- Example 1
    - Player 1 chooses an action which player 2 doesn't know
    - Player 2 assigns $Pr(L) = p$
    - (SP)NE: $\{(L,L'), (R,R')\}$
    - Requirement 1 & 2 eliminates $(R,R')$ as PBE since $L\succ_2 R'$ for any value of $p$

![PGT Figure 4.1.3](/post-img/notes-contract--job-signal-bayesian-1.png){width=390px}

|      |      | P2       |          |
| ---- | ---- | -------- | -------- |
|      |      | L'       | R'       |
| P1   | L    | \*2, 1\* | 0, 0     |
|      | M    | 0, 2\*   | 0, 1     |
|      | R    | 1, 3\*   | \*1, 3\* |

- Example 2
    - Player 2 chooses an action which player 3 doesn't know
    - Player 3 assigns $Pr(L) = p$
    - NE: $\{(D,L,R',p=1), (A,L,L',p=0)\}$
    - Requirement 4 eliminates $(A,L,L',p=0)$ as PBE since $p=0$ does not coincide with $L$

### Equilibrium Refinements

MWG 13.C, 13.Appendix, PGT 4.4

- Signalling dominated strategy  
$m_j\in M$ is dominated for type $t_i$ if exists $m_j'\in M$ s.t. $$\min_{a_k\in A} U_S(t_i, m_j', a_k)>\max_{a_k\in A} U_S(t_i, m_j, a_k)$$
- Signalling equilibrium-dominated strategy  
$m_j\in M$ is equilibrium-dominated for type $t_i$ if $$\underbrace{U^*(t_i)}_{\text{Equilibrium payoff}} > \max_{a_k\in A} \ U_S(t_i, m_j, a_k)$$
<!-- Given a PBE in a signaling game, message $m_j\in M$ is equilibrium-dominated for type $t_i\in T$ if $t_i$'s equilibrium payoff $U^*(t_i)$ is greater than $t_i$'s highest possible payoff from $m_j$  -->
- Requirement 5  
__Off-path beliefs__ should give $Pr=0$ on strictly dominated strategies at any information set
<!-- If possible, each player's beliefs off the equilibrium path should place zero probability on nodes that are reached only if another player plays a strategy that is strictly dominated beginning at some information set. -->
- Signalling requirement 5  
If off-path, belief $μ(t_i\ |\ m_j)\overset{!}{=}0$ for type $t_i$ playing dominated strategy $m_j$
<!-- If the information set following $m_j$ is off the equilibrium path and $m_j$ is dominated for type $t_i$, then (if possible) the Receiver's belief $μ(t_i\ |\ m_j)$ should place zero probability on type $t_i$.  
Possible provided $m_j$ is not dominated for all the types in T.-->
- Signalling requirement 6 (Intuitive criterion)  
If off-path, belief $μ(t_i\ |\ m_j)\overset{!}{=}0$ for type $t_i$ playing equilibrium-dominated strategy $m_j$
<!-- If the information set following $m_j$ is off the eqiulibrium path, and $m_j$ is equilibrium-dominated for type $t_i$, then (if possible) the Receiver's belief $μ(t_i\ |\ m_j)$ should place zero probability on type $t_i$.  
Possible provided $m_j$ is not equilibrium-dominated for all the types  -->
- Example 3
    - Player 1 chooses an action which player 2 doesn't know
    - Player 2 assigns $Pr(L) = p$
    - PBE: $\{(L,L',p=1), (R,R',p\leq\frac{1}{2})\}$
    - Requirement 5 eliminates $(R,R',p\leq\frac{1}{2})$ since $M$ is strictly dominated for player 1, therefore $1-p\overset{!}{=}0$

## Competitive Insurance Market

TIO Ch3, [Rothschild and Stiglitz (1976)](https://www.uh.edu/~bsorense/Rothschild&Stiglitz.pdf)

- Consumer's wealth: $W$
    - Cost of accident: $d$
- Probability of accident: $p$
- Insurance contract: $α = (α_1, α_2)$
    - Price: $α_1$
    - Payment: $α_1 + α_2$
    - Wealth with insurance (no accident): $W_1 = W-α_1$
    - Wealth with insurance (accident): $W_2 = W - d + α_2$
- Consumer's expected utility 
$$\begin{aligned}\hat{V}(p,W_1,W_2) = (1-p)\cdot U(W_1) + p\cdot U(W_2) \end{aligned}$$
- Firm's expected profit:
$$\begin{aligned}π(p, α) &= (1-p)\cdot α_1 - p\cdot α_2 \\
&= α_1 - p(α_1 + α_2)\end{aligned}$$
(PC) for consumer: $V(p,α) \geq V\big(p,(0,0)\big)$
- Equilibrium 
    - Consumer maximizes expected utility
    - All contracts in the equilibrium makes non-negative profit
    - All contracts outside the equilibrium makes negative profit

<!-- &= (1-p)\cdot (W - W_1) + p\cdot (W - W_2 - d)\\ &= W - pd - (1-p) W_1 - p\cdot W_2 -->

### Identical Consumers

- 1 type of consumers
- Consumer's problem:
$$\begin{aligned}\max_{W_1, W_2} && V(p,α) &= \hat{V}(p,W_1,W_2) \\
&& &= \hat{V}(p, W-α_1, W - d + α_2) \\
(PC) && π &= α_1 - p(α_1 + α_2) \\
&& &= W - p\cdot d - (1-p)\cdot W_1 - p\cdot W_2 \end{aligned}$$
Lagrangian:
$$\begin{aligned}\mathcal{L} &= (1-p)U(W_1) + p\cdot U(W_2) \\
&\phantom{\ggg} + λ\big( W - p\cdot d - (1-p)\cdot W_1 - p\cdot W_2 - π\big) \\
\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial W_1} &= (1-p)U'(W_1) - (1-p)λ \overset{!}{=} 0 \\
\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial W_2} &= p\cdot U'(W_2) - p\cdot λ \overset{!}{=} 0 \\
U'(W_1) - λ &= U'(W_2) - λ \\
U'(W_1) &= U'(W_2)\end{aligned}$$
- Perfect competition gives zero profit 
$$\begin{aligned}π &= α_1 - p(α_1 + α_2)\\
&= W - p\cdot d - (1-p)\cdot W_1 - p\cdot W_2 \\
&= 0 \end{aligned}$$
- Point $E$: consumer's endowment (outside option)
- Line $FE$: firm's zero-profit isoprofit

![RS(1976) Figure 1](/post-img/notes-contract--insurance-benchmark.png){width=621px}

### Different Types of Consumers

- Types of consumers: $p\in\{ p_H, p_L\}$, $p_H>p_L$
    - $Pr(p = p_H) = λ$
    - Average type: $\bar{p} = λ\cdot p_H + (1-λ)p_L$
- Point E: $p_H$ and $p_L$'s endowment (outside option)
- Non-existence of pooling equilibrium:  
FSOC $α$ is an PE, $α\succ_H E$ and $α\succ_L E$  
$\implies π = α_1 - \bar{p}(α_1 + α_2) = 0$  
$\implies$ the slope of line $αE$ is $\frac{1-\bar{p}}{\bar{p}}$  
Consider $β$: $β\succ_L α$ and $α\succ_H β$  
$\implies$ L types choose $β$, H types stick with $α$  
$\implies$ profit decreases

![RS(1976) Figure 2](/post-img/notes-contract--insurance-PE.png){width=500px}

- Potential seperating equilibrium:
    - Zero-profit isoprofits: $LE$, $HE$
    - H type: $α_H\succ_H E$, $α_H\sim_H α_L$
    - L type: $β\succ_L α_L\succ_L E$ , but $β$ is not the L type contract since $β\succ_H α_H$  

![RS(1976) Figure 3](/post-img/notes-contract--insurance-SE1.png){width=517px}

- Non-existence of seperating equilibrium with small $λ$:
    - $λ\to 0$, $F'E\to LE$
    - Exists $λ$ s.t. $λ\succ_H α_H$, $λ\succ_L α_L$  
    $\implies$ pooling  
    $\implies$ no equilibrium
    - As long as the green-shaded area between $\bar{U}^L$ and $F'E$ exists, this is the case

![RS(1976) Figure 3](/post-img/notes-contract--insurance-SE2.png){width=505px}

> Mock.Q1  
> Consider a market for loans to finance investment projects.  
> Investing requires an outlay of 1 dollar.  
> There are two types of projects, good and bad. A good project yields profit $π$ with probability $g$ and zero with $1-g$.  
> A bad project yields profit $π$ with $b$ and zero with $1-b$, where $g>b$.  
> The fraction of good projects is $λ$.  
> Entrepreneurs have no money but can borrow from banks, entrepreneurs know their type, banks don't.  
> A loan contract specifies repayment $R$.  
> Suppose banks can obtain funds at rate $r$ (or, equivalently, the opportunity cost of one dollar for a bank is $1 + r$).  
> Everybody is risk neutral, banks are competitive.  
> Assume that $gπ - (1+r) > 0 > bπ - (1+r)$.
> 
> 1. Find the equilibrium level of $R$ and the set of projects financed.
> 2. Suppose now that the entrepreneur can offer to contribute a fraction $x$ of the initial outlay.  
> Important: while the entrepreneur has some money to put on the table in the beginning of the game, she cannot store this money; that is, she still can only repay when the outcome of the project is good.  
> The cost to the entrepreneur is $(1 + ρ) x$ where $ρ > r$.  
> Write the entrepreneur's payoff function.
> 3. Suppose the timing of the game is that first the entrepreneur puts $x$ dollars on the table, and then the bank(s) make contract offers specifying $R$.  
> Describe the separating equilibrium in which the good type's utility is highest.

1. Since E have no money, their repayment to B is zero if the project fails  
Good E borrows to invest if 
$$\begin{aligned}g\cdot (π - R) + (1-g)\cdot (0 - 0)&\geq 0 \\
π - R &\geq 0 \end{aligned}$$
Bad E borrows to invest if 
$$\begin{aligned}b\cdot (π - R) + (1-b)\cdot (0 - 0)&\geq 0 \\
π - R &\geq 0 \end{aligned}$$
therefore, if $π \geq R$, both types will invest.  
Under competition, B is willing to lend money if 
$$\begin{aligned}\underbrace{-1}_{\text{Lend}} + \underbrace{λgR + (1-λ)bR}_{\text{Repayment}} &= r \\
R\big( λg + (1-λ)b \big) &= 1+r \\
R &= \frac{1+r}{λg + (1-λ)b} \end{aligned}$$
Therefore, when $λ$ is s.t. 
$$\begin{aligned}π - R &\geq 0 \\
π - \frac{1+r}{λg + (1-λ)b} &\geq 0\end{aligned}$$
all projects will be undertaken
2. Good type: $g\big(π-R(x)\big) - (1+ρ)x$  
Bad type: $b\big(π-R(x)\big) - (1+ρ)x$
3. Let the separating contract be $\begin{cases}x_g \\ R(x_g) \end{cases}$ and $\begin{cases}x_b \\ R(x_b) \end{cases}$
    a. Banks offer $R(x_b)$ s.t. they are indifferent between investing and no investing to bad types  
    $$\begin{aligned}R(x_b)\cdot b  &= (1-x_b)(1+r) \\
    b\big(π-R(x_b)\big) - (1+ρ)x_b &= bπ - (1-x_b)(1+r) - (1+ρ)x_b \\
    &= \underbrace{bπ - (1+r)}_{<0} - x_b(\underbrace{ρ-r}_{>0}) \\
    &< 0\end{aligned}$$
    therefore, bad types will not finance the investment  
    b. Banks offer $R(x_g)$ s.t. they are indifferent between investing and no investing to good types  
    $$\begin{aligned}R(x_g)\cdot g  &= (1-x_g)(1+r) \\
    g\big(π-R(x_g)\big) - (1+ρ)x_g &= gπ - (1-x_g)(1+r) - (1+ρ)x_g \\
    &= gπ - (1+r) - x_g(ρ-r)\end{aligned}$$
    c. $x_g$ must not satisfy bad type's (PC):
    $$\begin{aligned}b\big(π-R(x_g)\big) - (1+ρ)x_g &\leq 0 \\
    bπ - R(x_g)\cdot b - (1+ρ)x_g &\leq 0 \\
    bπ - \frac{b}{g} (1-x_g)(1+r) - (1+ρ)x_g &\leq 0 \\
    x_g &\geq \frac{bπ - \frac{b}{g}(1+r)}{-\frac{b}{g}(1+r) + (1+ρ)} \\
    &= x_g^*\end{aligned}$$

## Screening: Non-Linear Pricing

- Screening: induce buyers to __self-select__ with a menu of different contracts
    - Self selection: second degree price discrimination  
- Selection by indicators: third degree
- Perfect discrimination: first degree
- Price discrimination requires no resale

### Perfect Information: Monopoly

- Drivers type: $θ\in\{θ_1, θ_2\}$, $θ_1<θ_2$
    - $Pr(θ = θ_1) = λ$
- Utility function: $U=\begin{cases}θ\cdot V(s) - T & \text{Consume }s\text{ and pay }T \\ 0 &\text{Otherwise}\end{cases}$
    - $V'>0$, $V''<0$
    - Example: $V(s) = \frac{1-(1-s)^2}{2}$
- Cost of production: $c$
    - $c<θ_1<θ_2$
- Bundle: $(s_1, T_1)$, $(s_2, T_2)$
- Monopolist's problem:
$$\begin{aligned}\max_{s_1,s_2,T_1,T_2} && &λ\cdot(T_1 - c\cdot s_1) + (1-λ)\cdot(T_2 - c\cdot s_2) \\
(PC1) && &θ_1\cdot V(s_1) - T_1 \geq 0 \\
(PC2) && &θ_2\cdot V(s_2) - T_2 \geq 0\end{aligned}$$
Plug in 
$$\begin{aligned}\max_{s_1,s_2} && λ\cdot(θ_1\cdot V(s_1) - c\cdot s_1) &+ (1-λ)\cdot(θ_2\cdot V(s_2) - c\cdot s_2) \\
FOC && \frac{\partial}{\partial s_i}θ_i\cdot V(s_i)- c\cdot s_i &= 0 \\
&& \underbrace{θ_i\cdot V'(s_i^*)}_{MU} &= \underbrace{c}_{MC} \\
&& T_i^* &= θ_i\cdot V(s_i^*)\end{aligned}$$

### Asymmetric Information

- Monopolist's problem:
$$\begin{aligned}\max_{s_1,s_2,T_1,T_2} && &λ\cdot(T_1 - c\cdot s_1) + (1-λ)\cdot(T_2 - c\cdot s_2) \\
(PC1) && &θ_1\cdot V(s_1) - T_1 \geq 0 \\
(PC2) && &θ_2\cdot V(s_2) - T_2 \geq 0 \\
(IC1) && &θ_1\cdot V(s_1) - T_1 \geq θ_1\cdot V(s_2) - T_2 \\
(IC2) && &θ_2\cdot V(s_2) - T_2 \geq θ_2\cdot V(s_1) - T_1 \end{aligned}$$
(PC1) is binding  
(IC2) is binding since $θ_2$ type is tempted to choose $(s_1, T_1)$  
(IC2) $\implies$
$$\begin{aligned}θ_2\cdot V(s_2) - T_2 &\geq θ_2\cdot V(s_1) - T_1 \\
&\geq \underbrace{(θ_2-θ_1)\cdot V(s_1)}_{\geq 0} + \underbrace{θ_1\cdot V(s_1)- T_1}_{(PC1)} \\
&\geq 0\end{aligned}$$
$\implies$ (PC2) is redundant, therefore, 
$$\begin{aligned}θ_1\cdot V(s_1) - T_1 &= 0 \\
T_1 &= θ_1\cdot V(s_1) \\
&\implies\text{No rent at the bottom} \\
θ_2\cdot V(s_2) - T_2 &= θ_2\cdot V(s_1) - T_1 \\
&= θ_2\cdot V(s_1) - θ_1\cdot V(s_1) \\
&= (θ_2 - θ_1)\cdot V(s_1) \\
T_2 &= θ_2\cdot V(s_2) - \underbrace{(θ_2 - θ_1)\cdot V(s_1)}_{\text{Information rent}}\end{aligned}$$
Plug back into monopolist's problem 
$$\begin{aligned}\max_{s_1,s_2} && λ\cdot(θ_1\cdot V(s_1) - c\cdot s_1) &+ (1-λ)\cdot\big(θ_2\cdot V(s_2)- (θ_2 - θ_1)\cdot V(s_1) - c\cdot s_2\big) \\
FOC && \frac{\partial}{\partial s_2} = θ_2\cdot V(s_2)- c\cdot s_2 &= 0 \\
&& θ_2\cdot V'(s_2^*) &= c \\
&& &\implies\text{No distortion at the top} \\
&& \frac{\partial}{\partial s_1} = λ\cdot(θ_1\cdot V(s_1) - c\cdot s_1) &+ (1-λ)\cdot\big(-(θ_2 - θ_1)\cdot V(s_1)\big) = 0\\
&& θ_1\cdot V'(s_2^*) &= \frac{c}{1-\frac{1-λ}{λ}\cdot\frac{θ_2 - θ_1}{θ_1}} \\
&& &\implies\text{Distortion below the top}\end{aligned}$$

> PS3.Q3  
> An airline wishes to determine optimal prices for business class and economy class tickets.  
> The airline has the following information.  
> There are two types of buyers.  
> Some buyers derive a relatively high value from consuming additional space on the airplane. Their utility from consuming $s$ units of space and paying a total airfare of $T$ is given by $8\sqrt{s} - T$.  
> Other travellers derive a relatively low utility from consuming space on an airplane. Their utility from consuming $s$ units of space and paying an airfare of $T$ is given by $2\sqrt{s} - T$.  
> The companies cost of producing $s$ units of space is equal to $s$; thus, there are no fixed costs and the marginal cost of producing space is equal to one.  
> The total mass of consumers is unity.  
> A fraction $γ$ derives a high marginal utility from consuming additional space, a fraction $1-γ$ derives a low marginal utility from consuming additional space.  
> The company cannot observe which customer has a high or a low demand; it wishes to offer two optimal bundles $\{\underline{s},\underline{T}\}$ and $\{\bar{s},\bar{T}\}$ to the two customer groups.  
> 
> 1. Write down the firm's maximization problem, including the relevant constraints.  
> 2. Derive $\{\underline{s},\underline{T}\}$ and $\{\bar{s},\bar{T}\}$, assuming that $γ$ is very small (see 3).
> 3. At which level of $γ$ is there a qualitative change in the optimal menu offered to consumers?  
> Explain why this change occurs.

1. Firm's problem:
$$\begin{aligned}\max_{\underline{s},\underline{T},\bar{s},\bar{T}} && &γ\cdot(\bar{T}-\bar{s}) + (1-γ)\cdot(\underline{T}-\underline{s}) \\
(PC)_H && &8\sqrt{\bar{s}} - \bar{T} \geq 0 \\
(PC)_L && &2\sqrt{\underline{s}} - \underline{T}\geq 0 \\
(IC)_H && &8\sqrt{\bar{s}} - \bar{T} \geq 8\sqrt{\underline{s}} - \underline{T} \\
(IC)_L && &2\sqrt{\underline{s}} - \underline{T}\geq 2\sqrt{\bar{s}} - \bar{T}\end{aligned}$$
2. Since (PC)L and (IC)H are binding,
$$\begin{aligned}\underline{T} &= 2\sqrt{\underline{s}} \\
\bar{T} &= 8\sqrt{\bar{s}} - 8\sqrt{\underline{s}} + \underline{T} \\
&= 8\sqrt{\bar{s}} - \big(\underbrace{8\sqrt{\underline{s}} - 2\sqrt{\underline{s}}}_{\text{Rent}}\big)\end{aligned}$$
plug into firm's problem
$$\begin{aligned}\max_{\underline{s},\bar{s}} && &\phantom{\ggg}γ\cdot\Big(8\sqrt{\bar{s}} - \big(8\sqrt{\underline{s}} - 2\sqrt{\underline{s}}\big)-\bar{s}\Big) + (1-γ)\cdot(2\sqrt{\underline{s}}-\underline{s}) \\
&& &= γ\cdot\big(8\sqrt{\bar{s}}-\bar{s} - 6\sqrt{\underline{s}}\big) + (1-γ)\cdot(2\sqrt{\underline{s}}-\underline{s}) \\
FOC && \frac{\partial}{\partial\bar{s}} &= γ\cdot\big(8\cdot\frac{1}{2}\cdot\bar{s}^{\frac{1}{2}} - 1\big) \overset{!}{=} 0\\
&& \bar{s}^* &= 16 \implies\text{No distortion at top} \\
&& \frac{\partial}{\partial\underline{s}} &= -6γ\cdot\frac{1}{2}\cdot\underline{s}^{-\frac{1}{2}} + (1-γ)\cdot\Big( 2\cdot\frac{1}{2}\cdot\underline{s}^{-\frac{1}{2}}-1\Big) \overset{!}{=} 0 \\
&& \underline{s}^* &= \Big(\frac{1-4γ}{1-γ}\Big)^2 \end{aligned}$$
3. When $\underline{s}$ exists, 
$$\begin{aligned}\sqrt{\underline{s}} &\geq 0 \\
\frac{1-4γ}{1-γ} &\geq 0 \\
(1-4γ)(1-γ) &\geq 0 \\
γ &\leq\frac{1}{4} \end{aligned}$$
therefore, when $γ>\frac{1}{4}$, low types are excluded from the menu.  
$\implies$ downwards distortion below the top

2. Airline's problem:

&= \frac{W_T - W_B}{θ_B} + \frac{v-W_T}{θ_T} \end{aligned}$$

    &= \frac{v}{θ_T} \\
    P_B^* &= \frac{W_T^* - W_B^*}{θ_B} + P_T^* \\
    &= \frac{v}{θ_T}\end{aligned}$$

### Continuous Types: Mechanism Approach

[Maskin and Riley (1984)](https://www.jstor.org/stable/pdf/2555674.pdf)

- Revelation principle
- Consumers' type: $θ\in [\underline{θ}, \bar{θ}]$
    - pdf: $f(θ)$
    - cdf: $F(θ)$
    - Consumers' statement: $\hat{θ}$
- Utility function: $U=\begin{cases}θ\cdot V(s) - T & \text{Consume }s\text{ and pay }T \\ 0 &\text{Otherwise}\end{cases}$
    - $V'>0$, $V''<0$
    - Example: $V(s) = \frac{1-(1-s)^2}{2}$
- Cost of production: $c< \underline{θ}$
- Consumers' problem:
$$\begin{aligned}\max_s && &θ\cdot V(s) - T(s) \\
\implies && &s^*(θ) \\
&& &T\big(s^*(θ)\big)\end{aligned}$$
- Price scheme: $\Big( s(θ), T\big(s(θ)\big)\Big)$ for all $θ$
- Firm's problem:
$$\begin{aligned}\max_{T(θ),s(θ)} && \int_{\underline{θ}}^{\bar{θ}} \big(T(θ) - c\cdot s(θ)\big)f(θ) \, dθ& \\
(PC) && θ\cdot V\big(s(θ)\big) - T(θ) &\geq 0 \\
(IC) && θ\cdot V\big(s(θ)\big) - T(θ) &\geq θ\cdot V(s(\hat{θ})) - T(\hat{θ})\end{aligned}$$
(IC) for type $θ$ and type $θ'\implies$ 
$$\begin{cases}θ\cdot V\big(s(θ)\big) - T(θ) \geq θ\cdot V\big(s(θ')\big) - T(θ') \\
θ'\cdot V\big(s(θ')\big) - T(θ') \geq θ'\cdot V\big(s(θ)\big) - T(θ) \end{cases}$$
therefore,
$$\begin{aligned}(θ-θ')\cdot \Big( V\big(s(θ)\big) -  V\big(s(θ')\big)\Big) \geq 0 \end{aligned}$$
Assume $s(θ)$ is monotonic, $s'(θ)\geq 0$  
$\implies V\big(s(θ)\big)$ is monotonic  
$\implies V\big(s(θ)\big)$ is differentiable almost everywhere  
$\implies$ FOC holds
- Consumer concerning statement $\hat{θ}$:
$$\begin{aligned}\max_{\hat{θ}} && &θ\cdot V\big(s(\hat{θ})\big) - T(\hat{θ}) \\
FOC && &θ\cdot V'\big(s(\hat{θ})\big)\cdot s'(\hat{θ}) - T'(\hat{θ})|_{\hat{θ}=θ} \overset{!}{=}0\end{aligned}$$
$$\begin{aligned}U(θ) &= \max_{\hat{θ}} \ θ\cdot V\big(s(\hat{θ})\big) - T(\hat{θ})\\
U'(θ) &= V\big(s(θ)\big) + \Big(\underbrace{θ\cdot V'\big(s(\hat{θ})\big)\cdot s'(\hat{θ}) - T'(\hat{θ})}_{FOC}\Big)\frac{d\hat{θ}}{dθ} \\
&= V\big(s(θ)\big) \geq 0\end{aligned}$$
$\implies$ (PC) is only binding at $\underline{θ}$, and slack anywhere else  
$\implies U(\underline{θ}) = 0$  
therefore,
$$\begin{aligned}U(θ) &= U(\underline{θ}) + \int_{\underline{θ}}^{θ} V\big(s(u)\big)\, du \\
&= \int_{\underline{θ}}^{θ} V\big(s(u)\big)\, du \\
&= θ\cdot  V\big(s(θ)\big) - T(θ) \\
T(θ) &= \underbrace{θ\cdot  V\big(s(θ)\big)}_{\text{Surplus}} - \underbrace{\int_{\underline{θ}}^{θ} V\big(s(u)\big)\, du}_{\text{Information rent}}\end{aligned}$$
- Firm's problem:
$$\begin{aligned}\max_{T(θ),s(θ)} && \int_{\underline{θ}}^{\bar{θ}} \big(T(θ) -c\cdot s(θ) \big)\cdot f(θ)\, dθ\end{aligned}$$
plug in $T(θ)$
$$\begin{aligned}\max_{s(θ)} && &\int_{\underline{θ}}^{\bar{θ}} \Big(θ\cdot  V\big(s(θ)\big) - \int_{\underline{θ}}^{θ} V\big(s(u)\big)\, du -c\cdot s(θ) \Big)\cdot f(θ)\, dθ \\
(IC) && &s'(θ)\geq 0\end{aligned}$$
Let $h'(θ) = V\big(s(θ)\big)$, integration by parts gives
$$\begin{aligned}&\phantom{\ggg}\int_{\underline{θ}}^{\bar{θ}} \Big(\underbrace{\int_{\underline{θ}}^{θ} V\big(s(u)\big)\, du}_{h(θ)}  \Big)\cdot \underbrace{f(θ)}_{F'(θ)}\, dθ \\
&= \Big(\int_{\underline{θ}}^{θ} V\big(s(u)\big)\, du\Big) \cdot F(θ)\Big|_{\underline{θ}}^{\bar{θ}} - \int_{\underline{θ}}^{\bar{θ}} V\big(s(θ)\big)\cdot F(θ)\, dθ \\
&= \int_{\underline{θ}}^{\bar{θ}} V\big(s(u)\big)\, du\cdot 1- \int_{\underline{θ}}^{\bar{θ}} V\big(s(u)\big)\, du \cdot F(θ) \\
&= \int_{\underline{θ}}^{\bar{θ}} V\big(s(u)\big)\cdot \big(1-F(θ)\big)\, du\end{aligned}$$
plug back into firm's problem
$$\begin{aligned}\max_{s(θ)} && &\phantom{\ggg}\int_{\underline{θ}}^{\bar{θ}} \Big(θ\cdot  V\big(s(θ)\big) - \int_{\underline{θ}}^{θ} V\big(s(u)\big)\, du -c\cdot s(θ) \Big)\cdot f(θ)\, dθ \\
&& &= \int_{\underline{θ}}^{\bar{θ}} \Big(θ\cdot  V\big(s(θ)\big)-c\cdot s(θ) \Big)\cdot f(θ)\, dθ - \int_{\underline{θ}}^{\bar{θ}} V\big(s(θ)\big)\cdot \big(1-F(θ)\big)\, dθ \\
&& &= \int_{\underline{θ}}^{\bar{θ}} \Big(θ\cdot  V\big(s(θ)\big)-c\cdot s(θ) \Big)\cdot f(θ)\, dθ - \int_{\underline{θ}}^{\bar{θ}} V\big(s(θ)\big)\cdot \big(\frac{1-F(θ)}{f(θ)}\big)\, f(θ)dθ \\
&& &= \int_{\underline{θ}}^{\bar{θ}} \Big(θ\cdot  V\big(s(θ)\big)-c\cdot s(θ) - V\big(s(θ)\big)\cdot \frac{1-F(θ)}{f(θ)} \Big)\cdot f(θ)\, dθ\end{aligned}$$
$$\begin{aligned}FOC && \frac{\partial}{\partial s(θ)} = θ\cdot V'(s(θ)) - c - V'(s(θ)) \cdot\frac{1-F(θ)}{f(θ)} &\overset{!}{=} 0 \\
&& \Big( θ\cdot V'\big(s(θ)\big) - c\Big) f(θ) &= V'\big(s(θ)\big) \cdot \big(1-F(θ)\big) \\
&& \frac{θ\cdot V'\big(s(θ)\big) - c}{V'\big(s(θ)\big)} &= \frac{\big(1-F(θ)\big)}{f(θ)} \end{aligned}$$


## Moral Hazard

CT Ch4

- Outcome: $q\in\{0,1\}$
    - $Pr(q=1\ |\ a) = p(a)$
    - $p(0)=0$, $p(\infty)=1$
    - $p'>0$, $p''<0$
- Principal's utility: $V(q-w)$
    - $V'>0$, $V''\leq 0$
- Agent's utility: $u(w) - a$

### First Best

- Assumption: $a$ is observable  
$\implies$ can write contract on effort: $\begin{cases}w_0 & a=a^*\text{, fail} \\ w_1 &a=a^*\text{, success} \\ K\to 0 & a\neq a^* \end{cases}$
- Social planner's problem:
$$\begin{aligned}\max_{a,w_i} && &p(a)\cdot V(1-w_1) + \big(1-p(a)\big)\cdot V(0-w_0) \\
(PC) && &p(a)\cdot u(w_1) + \big(1-p(a)\big)\cdot u(w_0) - a\geq 0\end{aligned}$$
let (PC) be binding, Lagrangian function:
$$\begin{aligned}\mathcal{L} &= p(a)\cdot V(1-w_1) + \big(1-p(a)\big)\cdot V(0-w_0) \\
&\phantom{\ggg} +λ\Big(p(a)\cdot u(w_1) + \big(1-p(a)\big)\cdot u(w_0) - a \Big) \\
\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial w_1} &= p(a)\cdot V'(1-w_1)\cdot (-1) + λ\cdot p(a)\cdot u'(w_1) \overset{!}{=} 0 \\
\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial w_0} &= \big(1-p(a)\big)\cdot V'(-w_0)\cdot (-1) + λ\cdot\big(1-p(a)\big)\cdot u'(w_0) \overset{!}{=} 0 \\
\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial a} &= p'(a)\cdot\big(V(1-w_1) - V(-w_0) \big) + λ\Big(p'(a)\cdot\big(u(w_1) - u(w_0)\big) - 1\Big) \overset{!}{=} 0\end{aligned}$$
$\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial w_1}$ and $\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial w_0}$ give
$$\begin{aligned}V'(1-w_1) &= λ\cdot u'(w_1) \\
V'(-w_0) &= λ\cdot u'(w_0) \\
λ = \frac{V'(1-w_1)}{u'(w_1)} &= \frac{V'(-w_0)}{u'(w_0)} \\
\frac{V'(1-w_1)}{V'(-w_0)} &= \frac{u'(w_1)}{u'(w_0)} \\
\text{Principal's } MRS &= \text{Agent's } MRS\end{aligned}$$
$\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial a}$ gives
$$\begin{aligned}p'(a)\cdot\big(V(1-w_1) - V(-w_0) \big) + λ\Big(p'(a)\cdot\big(u(w_1) - u(w_0)\big) - 1\Big) &= 0 \\
p'(a)\cdot\big(V(1-w_1) - V(-w_0) \big) + λp'(a)\cdot\big(u(w_1) - u(w_0)\big) - λ &= 0 \\
p'(a)\cdot\big(V(1-w_1) - V(-w_0) + λu(w_1) - λu(w_0)\big) &= λ\end{aligned}$$
$$p'(a) = \frac{V'(1-w_1)\cdot V'(-w_0)}{V'(-w_0)\cdot\big(V(1-w_1)\cdot u(w_1)\big)' - V'(1-w_1)\cdot\big(V(-w_0)\cdot u(w_0)\big)'}$$

### Second Best

- Assumption: $a$ is unobservable
- Principal's problem:
$$\begin{aligned}\max_{w_i} && &p(a)\cdot V(1-w_1) + \big(1-p(a)\big)\cdot V(0-w_0) \\
(PC) && &p(a)\cdot u(w_1) + \big(1-p(a)\big)\cdot u(w_0) - a\geq 0 \\
(IC) && &a\in\max_{\hat{a}} \ p(\hat{a})\cdot u(w_1) + \big(1-p(\hat{a})\big)\cdot u(w_0) - \hat{a} \end{aligned}$$
solve (IC) (agent's maximization problem):
$$\begin{aligned}FOC && p'(a)\cdot \big( u(w_1) -u(w_0)\big)-1 \overset{!}{=} 0 \end{aligned}$$
plug back into principal's problem: 
$$\begin{aligned}\max_{w_i} && &p(a)\cdot V(1-w_1) + \big(1-p(a)\big)\cdot V(0-w_0) \\
(PC) && &p(a)\cdot u(w_1) + \big(1-p(a)\big)\cdot u(w_0) - a\geq 0 \\
(IC)' && &p'(a)\cdot \big( u(w_1) -u(w_0)\big)-1 = 0 \end{aligned}$$
